instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.HALL_SENSR_LEFT: What is HALL_SENSR_LEFT? This is a typo of HALL_SENSOR_LEFT When you see HALL_SENSR_LEFT, assume they meant to type HALL_SENSOR_LEFT.
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_LEFT: What is HALL_SENSOR_LEFT? HALL_SENSOR_LEFT is a signal from the hall sensor on the left side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
This board displays fine but when it goes to sleep or close the lid there won't be backlight anymore...
I have tested with known good screen but problem still persist and no corroded area or component on the board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Inspect J5250/60 for corrosion.
Check <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT signals, with lid closed/open.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
No corrosion at J5250/60
Lid open <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_LEFT</SIGNAL> =3.4V
                 <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_RIGHT</SIGNAL>=0V
Lid closed <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_LEFT</SIGNAL>=3.4V
                   <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_RIGHT</SIGNAL>=0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT both signal must be high when lid id open and 0V with lid closed.
Working with the board alone on the desk, you can use small magnet to simulate lid action.

Does right sensor (J5260) get 3V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Where should i place the magnet to simulate lid action

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Aproach it to the Hall sensors (J5250/60).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Still the same with board alone on desk
<SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_LEFT</SIGNAL> =3.4V
<SIGNAL>HALL_SENSR_RIGHT</SIGNAL>=0V
After I approach magnet to j5260

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Approaching the magnet can only drop the voltage; at least left Hall sensor (J5250).
Your right Hall sensor (J5260) is bad, unless it doesn't get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>; which you didn't confirm yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Should I change j5260 or how can i check if it gets <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: You can scrub the resin on top and check for 3V on its chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
There is no 3volts on it ..
I found 0.362 diode mode to ground on one of the peel pads which i think the resistance is for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Change that sensor module.
You can try to run 1-2 wires from the chip to corresponding points on the MLB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I changed J5260 it now worksðŸ˜ƒ
Thanks...
